feed.title: Current watches, warnings, and advisories for United States land zones

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 4 at 2:31PM CST by NWS New Orleans LA
entry.summary:
At 231 PM CST, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over Geismar, or near Gonzales, moving northeast at 25 mph.
HAZARD...Winds in excess of 30 mph and pea size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.
Locations impacted include... Gonzales, Donaldsonville, St. Gabriel, Walker, Sorrento, French Settlement, Port Vincent, Prairieville, Geismar, and Whitehall.
This includes the following Interstates... Interstate 10 in Louisiana between mile markers 170 and 197. Interstate 12 between mile markers 16 and 20.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Iberville; St. James; St. John The Baptist; Northern Livingston; Southern Livingston; Western Ascension; Eastern Ascension

cap:parameter.value: A STRONG THUNDERSTORM WILL IMPACT PORTIONS OF NORTHWESTERN ST. JOHN THE BAPTIST, ASCENSION, NORTHERN ST. JAMES, SOUTHWESTERN LIVINGSTON AND EAST CENTRAL IBERVILLE PARISHES THROUGH 315 PM CST

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued March 4 at 2:30PM CST until March 4 at 3:15PM CST by NWS Jackson MS
entry.summary:
SVRJAN
The National Weather Service in Jackson has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... West central Morehouse Parish in northeastern Louisiana...
* Until 315 PM CST.
* At 229 PM CST, a severe thunderstorm was located near Bastrop, moving northeast at 20 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
* This severe thunderstorm will be near... Bastrop, Mer Rouge, and Collinston around 235 PM CST.

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued March 4 at 2:28PM CST until March 4 at 3:30PM CST by NWS Shreveport LA
entry.summary:
SVRSHV
The National Weather Service in Shreveport has issued a
* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Southeastern Union County in south central Arkansas... Northeastern Union Parish in north central Louisiana...
* Until 330 PM CST.
* At 228 PM CST, a severe thunderstorm was located near Lapile, or near Huttig, moving northeast at 20 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
* Locations impacted include... Huttig, Lapile, and Felsenthal.
Monitoring message only. Please disregard.

entry.title: High Wind Warning issued March 4 at 1:23PM MST until March 5 at 11:00AM MST by NWS Cheyenne WY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...West to southwest winds 35 to 45 MPH with gusts up to 65 MPH possible.
* WHERE...Southeast Wyoming wind-prone areas including Interstate 80 near Arlington, South Laramie Range and adjacent Foothills including Interstate 80 between Laramie and Cheyenne, and Interstate 25 in Platte County including Bordeaux, Wheatland, and Glendo.
* WHEN...5 PM this afternoon until 11 AM MST Tuesday. The strongest winds are expected overnight.
* IMPACTS...Mainly to transportation. Strong cross winds will be hazardous to light weight or high profile vehicles, including campers and tractor trailers.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Laramie Range and Southwest Platte County; North Snowy Range Foothills; South Laramie Range; South Laramie Range Foothills

cap:parameter.value: HIGH WIND WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 11 AM MST TUESDAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 4 at 12:22PM PST until March 5 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations of 6 to 12 inches at elevations above 4000 feet, locally up to 2 feet at highest peaks. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County, Burney Basin / Eastern Shasta County and Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Western Colusa County Counties.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels around 3000 to 4000 feet through this evening, rising to 4000 to 5500 feet by Tuesday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County; Burney Basin / Eastern Shasta County; Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Western Colusa County

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM PST TUESDAY

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued March 4 at 4:01PM AST until March 4 at 6:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip currents due to breaking waves up to 6-7 feet.
* WHERE...Beaches of Aguada and Rincon, as well as northern beaches of St. Thomas and St. John.
* WHEN...Through 6 PM AST tonight.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents that can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water where it becomes difficult to return to safety.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Mayaguez and Vicinity; St.Thomas...St. John.. and Adjacent Islands

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AST THIS EVENING

cap:parameter.value: A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of eastern Mercer, south central Rock Island, west central Henry and southeastern Scott Counties through 245 PM CST

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 4 at 3:00PM EST by NWS Melbourne FL
entry.summary:
Dense marine fog is occurring across the Volusia County and northern Space Coast Atlantic waters. Some of this fog will impact the barrier islands from Cape Canaveral northward this afternoon, before winds veer onshore overnight and bring the fog farther inland. Localized visibilities around a mile or less will be possible along the coast through sunset. Use caution on the roads through tonight.
Drivers should prepare to encounter rapid visibility reductions. When driving in fog, slow down, use only low beam headlights, and leave extra following distance between your vehicle and the one in front of you.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Coastal Volusia; Northern Brevard Barrier Islands

cap:parameter.value: Patchy Dense Fog Along The Barrier Islands From Cape Canaveral Northward

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued March 4 at 3:58PM AST until March 4 at 6:00PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of Puerto Rico, including the following county, Mayaguez.
* WHEN...Until 600 PM AST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Rises in small streams and normally dry arroyos. Overflowing poor drainage areas. Some low-water crossings may become impassable. Ponding of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 356 PM AST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in urban and small stream flooding. - Eastern Mayaguez. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM AST THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued March 4 at 3:41PM AST until March 4 at 5:45PM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of Puerto Rico, including the following county, Ponce.
* WHEN...Until 545 PM AST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Overflowing poor drainage areas. Some low-water crossings may become impassable. Ponding of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 339 PM AST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. Between 1 and 2.5 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - In the west central portion of the municipality of Ponce. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 4 at 1:34PM CST by NWS Green Bay WI
entry.summary: A narrow band of rain has already shifted, or will soon shift to snow this afternoon from central Wisconsin into north central Wisconsin. Snow is already occurring in the Wausau area. Where snow occurs as the primary precipitation type from central to north central Wisconsin, plan on an inch or two of wet snow, especially on grassy surfaces. As the snow continues, a thin layer of slush may also begin to accumulate on untreated or less traveled roads. Use caution if traveling this afternoon as it could become slippery in some areas even as temperatures remain just above freezing.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Vilas; Oneida; Forest; Lincoln; Langlade; Marathon

cap:parameter.value: RAIN SHIFTING TO SNOW CENTRAL WISCONSIN TO NORTH CENTRAL WISCONSIN

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 4 at 11:13AM PST until March 4 at 9:00PM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 7 to 11 feet and dangerous rip currents, diminishing to 6 to 9 feet this evening. Highest surf on west and northwest facing beaches.
* WHERE...San Luis Obispo County Beaches and Santa Barbara County Central Coast Beaches.
* WHEN...Until 9 PM PST this evening.
* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large breaking waves can cause injury, wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats near shore.
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Luis Obispo County Beaches; Santa Barbara County Central Coast Beaches

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM PST THIS EVENING

* IMPACTS...Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 45 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 11:58AM CST by NWS Shreveport LA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Louisiana...
Bodcau Bayou At Bayou Bodcau Lake affecting Webster and Bossier Parishes.
For the Bodcau Bayou...including Bayou Bodcau Lake...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Bodcau Bayou at Bayou Bodcau Lake.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:00 AM CST Monday the stage was 175.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 171.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:00 AM CST Monday was 175.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 175.0 feet this afternoon. - Flood stage is 172.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 175.0 feet on 05/29/1968. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.summary:
...The Flood Advisory continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Columbia affecting Richland and Lexington Counties.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Congaree River at Columbia.
* WHEN...Until later this evening.
* IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Flooding occurs in flood prone areas near and downstream from Columbia. Flooding also occurs on parts of the Cayce and West Columbia river walk.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:00 PM EST Monday the stage was 10.1 feet. - Bankfull stage is 19.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 6.9 feet Saturday morning. - Action stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood stage is 19.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 12:54PM EST until March 6 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Columbia SC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Congaree National Park-Gadsden affecting Richland and Calhoun Counties.
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Richland, Calhoun and Lexington Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Congaree River at Carolina Eastman.
* WHEN...Until Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 115.0 feet, Flooding occurs in low lying areas of the Carolina Eastman Facility and at the Congaree National Park. At 119.0 feet, Extensive flooding occurs in the Congaree National Park. Some area farmland is flooded. Minor flooding occurs at the Carolina Eastman Facility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:48 PM EST Monday the stage was 117.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 114.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage tomorrow morning and continue falling to 112.5 feet Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 115.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Calhoun, SC; Lexington, SC; Richland, SC

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL WEDNESDAY MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 12:54PM EST until March 7 at 1:00PM EST by NWS Columbia SC
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Congaree National Park-Gadsden affecting Richland and Calhoun Counties.
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...
Congaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Richland, Calhoun and Lexington Counties.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Congaree River at Congaree National Park-Gadsden.
* WHEN...Until early Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Flooding begins in the Congaree National Park. This will begin to produce flooding of portions of the lower boardwalk. At 17.0 feet, The access road to the Sandy Run subdivision becomes flooded. The lower boardwalk in the Congaree National Park becomes flooded by Cedar Creek. At 18.0 feet, Several homes in the Sandy Run subdivision along the river become flooded. At 18 feet the river covers the Weston Lake overlook in the Congaree National Park. Between 18 and 18.5 feet the river begins to cover sections of the elevated boardwalk.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:00 PM EST Monday the stage was 16.8 feet. - Bankfull stage is 14.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage early Wednesday afternoon and continue falling to 14.4 feet Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY THURSDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 5 at 3:06AM ChST until March 5 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 7 to 9 feet.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Kosrae.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM ChST this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The long-period north swell will continue to slowly subside. Surf will remain elevated along north and east facing reefs through this afternoon, falling below hazardous levels later today. Surf is expected to build again Wednesday along east facing reefs as a building trade swell moves into the the region.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM CHST THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 4 at 10:05AM MST until March 6 at 5:00AM MST by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow and areas of blowing snow expected. Total snow accumulations mostly between 1 and 3 inches in the valleys and 3 to 6 inches in the mountains. However, the West Yellowstone area could receive up to 6 inches, with some adjacent peaks possibly getting up to 12 inches. Winds gusting as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...Gallatin and Madison County Mountains and Centennial Mountains, Madison River Valley, and Ruby Mountains and Southern Beaverhead Mountains.
* WHEN...From 5 AM Tuesday to 5 AM MST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The peak period for snow and blowing snow looks to be during the day on Tuesday, with activity decreasing gradually Tuesday night.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 10:32AM CST by NWS Lake Charles LA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas... Louisiana...
Sabine River Near Deweyville
For the Sabine River...including Burkeville, Bon Wier, Deweyville, Orange...Minor flooding is forecast.
Additional information is available at www.weather.gov.
The next statement will be issued Tuesday morning at 1045 AM CST.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Sabine River near Deweyville.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 24.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding will occur.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 AM CST Monday the stage was 24.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:45 AM CST Monday was 24.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to remain steady above flood stage at 24.4 feet. - Flood stage is 24.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Beauregard, LA; Calcasieu, LA; Newton, TX; Orange, TX

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Wind Chill Advisory issued March 4 at 6:35AM AKST until March 4 at 12:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...WINTRY WEATHER FOR THE PANHANDLE...
.Northerly outflow winds will diminish through Monday morning, but lingering gusts along the Klondike Highway. These winds combined with temperatures as low as 9 below zero will cause wind chills to 40 below zero.
.A passing front will give the NE gulf coast, including Yakutat, snow beginning Monday evening. Heaviest snow is likely Monday night. As temperatures warm, rain is expected to mix in Tuesday morning with a rain/snow mix lasting through the rest of the day.
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills. Wind chills as low as 40 below zero.
* WHERE...Klondike Highway.
* WHEN...Until noon AKST Monday.
* IMPACTS...The cold wind chills could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.

cap:parameter.value: WIND CHILL ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL NOON AKST TODAY

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 4 at 6:35AM AKST until March 5 at 12:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...WINTRY WEATHER FOR THE PANHANDLE...
.Northerly outflow winds will diminish through Monday morning, but lingering gusts along the Klondike Highway. These winds combined with temperatures as low as 9 below zero will cause wind chills to 40 below zero.
.A passing front will give the NE gulf coast, including Yakutat, snow beginning Monday evening. Heaviest snow is likely Monday night. As temperatures warm, rain is expected to mix in Tuesday morning with a rain/snow mix lasting through the rest of the day.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 6 inches.
* WHERE...City and Borough of Yakutat.
* WHEN...From 9 PM Monday to noon AKST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow will start out light before picking up during the overnight hours. The heaviest snow will be during the overnight and early morning hours before snowfall rates start to diminish. Snow will start to mix with rain towards the mid morning to afternoon on Tuesday.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 9 PM THIS EVENING TO NOON AKST TUESDAY

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued March 4 at 7:43AM MST by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
AVWBOU
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...AVALANCHE WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 7 AM Monday UNTIL 5 PM Monday...
*WHAT... The Avalanche Danger is HIGH (Level 4 of 5)
*WHERE... Areas around and east of Crested Butte north through Aspen including the Elk Mountains
*WHEN... In effect from 7 AM Monday, March 4 until 5 PM Monday, March 4
*IMPACTS... Heavy snow and strong winds have created dangerous avalanche conditions in the backcountry. Large and dangerous avalanches will be very easy to trigger. Avalanches will run naturally.
*PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Travel in backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended.Avoid travel on and under slopes steeper than about 30 degrees. You can find more detailed information at colorado.gov/avalanche
entry.cap:areaDesc: Gore and Elk Mountains/Central Mountain Valleys; West Elk and Sawatch Mountains

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM HST THIS EVENING

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 4 at 3:22AM HST until March 5 at 6:00AM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FOR MAUI AND BIG ISLAND THROUGH LATE TONIGHT...
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...The Big Island.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Flood prone roads and other low lying areas may be closed due to elevated runoff and overflowing streams. Urban areas may receive more significant flooding and property damage due to rapid runoff.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - An upper level trough moving in from the west will tap into a more moist environment over the eastern half of the state. A jet stream leading this trough will enhance periods of moderate to locally heavy rainfall. The heaviest rainfall amounts are forecast to fall along the eastern slopes of the Big Island from North Kohala, down the Hamakua Coast, into the Hilo and Puna Districts.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Kona; Kohala; Big Island Interior; Big Island Summit; Big Island South; Big Island Southeast; Big Island East; Big Island North

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 4 at 3:22AM HST until March 5 at 6:00AM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FOR MAUI AND BIG ISLAND THROUGH LATE TONIGHT...
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...The island of Maui in Maui County.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Flood prone roads and other low lying areas may be closed due to elevated runoff and overflowing streams. Urban areas may receive more significant flooding and property damage due to rapid runoff.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - An upper level trough moving in from the west will tap into a more moist environment over the eastern half of the state. A jet stream leading this trough will enhance periods of moderate to locally heavy rainfall. The heaviest rainfall amounts are forecast to fall along the windward slope of Haleakala in East Maui.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Maui Windward West; Maui Leeward West; Haleakala Summit; Maui Central Valley North; Maui Central Valley South; Windward Haleakala; Kipahulu; South Maui/Upcountry; South Haleakala

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 4 at 3:56AM AKST until March 4 at 12:00PM AKST by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow and blowing snow. Additional snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph. Visibility reduced to one-half mile at times along the coast.
* WHERE...Bristol Bay.
* WHEN...Until noon AKST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on difficult travel conditions. Blowing snow could cause significant reductions in visibility.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The blowing snow threat has ended for the Western Capes. The lowest visibilities will be most likely along the coast in the vicinity of Dillingham, including Clarks Point, over the next several hours before winds diminish. Areas in the vicinity of Dillingham, including the communities of Clarks Point, Manokotak, and Aleknagik will continue to see moderate snowfall rates through the morning hours. These areas have the greatest chance at seeing storm total snow accumulations of around 6 inches.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 4 at 2:22AM PST until March 5 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Winter Storm Warning, heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 8 to 14 inches. Winds gusting as high as 50 mph over exposed terrain. For the Winter Weather Advisory, snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 5 inches.
* WHERE...For the Winter Storm Warning, northern sections of Lake and Klamath County. This includes much of highway 97, portions of highways 31, 140, and 395, and the communities of Christmas Valley, Chemult, Chiloquin, Lakeview, and Valley Falls. The Winter Weather Advisory includes Modoc Point and Klamath Falls, Crescent, Silver Lake, Fort Rock, and Paisley.
* WHEN...From 10 AM Monday to 4 PM PST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels will be about 1500 feet to the north and 4500 feet to the south.
* View the hazard area in detail at https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/map/?wfo=mfr
entry.cap:areaDesc: Klamath Basin; Northern and Eastern Klamath County and Western Lake County; Central and Eastern Lake County

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 4 at 4:58AM EST until March 4 at 9:00PM EST by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Rhode Island...Connecticut...
Wood River At Hope Valley affecting Washington County.
Pawcatuck River At Westerly affecting Washington and New London Counties.
For the Pawcatuck River...including Wood River Junction, Westerly... Minor flooding is forecast. For the Wood River...including Hope Valley...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Pawcatuck River at Westerly.
* WHEN...Until late this evening.
* IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding occurs along the Pawcatuck River. Along Route 3 in Hopkinton, floodwaters encroach on lowest lying homes in French Village.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:00 AM EST Monday the stage was 7.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 7.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 4:00 AM EST Monday was 7.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late this afternoon and continue falling to 6.7 feet Wednesday evening. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued March 4 at 2:48AM MST until March 6 at 5:00AM MST by NWS Pocatello ID
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 6 inches. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Arco/Mud Lake Desert, Upper Snake River Plain, Lower Snake River Plain, Marsh/Arbon Highlands, and Beaverhead/Lemhi Highlands. This includes Mud Lake, INL, Craters of the Moon NM, Idaho Falls, Rexburg, St. Anthony, Pocatello, Blackfoot, American Falls, Shelley, Fort Hall, Inkom, McCammon, Downey, Lava Hot Springs, Dubois, Spencer, Edie School, and Small.
* WHEN...From 5 AM Tuesday to 5 AM MST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be difficult. Areas of blowing and drifting snow could significantly reduce visibility.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Arco/Mud Lake Desert; Upper Snake River Plain; Lower Snake River Plain; Marsh and Arbon Highlands; Beaverhead/Lemhi Highlands

cap:parameter.value: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 5 AM TUESDAY TO 5 AM MST WEDNESDAY

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued March 4 at 2:48AM MST until March 6 at 11:00AM MST by NWS Pocatello ID
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 5 to 10 inches, except 3 to 6 inches in Caribou County and 10 to 20 inches on ridge tops and elevations above passes possible. Winds could gust as high as 50 mph.
* WHERE...Bear River Range, Blackfoot Mountains, Caribou Range, Big Hole Mountains, Teton Valley, and Centennial Mountains. This includes Emigration Summit, Grace, Soda Springs, Henry, Bone, Wayan, Swan Valley, Victor, Ashton, Tetonia, Driggs, Island Park, and Kilgore.
* WHEN...From early Tuesday morning through Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing and drifting snow could significantly reduce visibility.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bear River Range; Blackfoot Mountains; Caribou Range; Big Hole Mountains; Teton Valley; Centennial Mountains/Island Park

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM EARLY TUESDAY MORNING THROUGH WEDNESDAY MORNING

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued March 4 at 1:52AM MST until March 6 at 11:00AM MST by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 12 to 20 inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 55 mph.
* WHERE...Teton and Gros Ventre Mountains.
* WHEN...From late tonight through Wednesday morning. The heaviest snow is expected on Tuesday night.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY MORNING

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued March 4 at 1:52AM MST until March 6 at 11:00AM MST by NWS Riverton WY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations ranging from 9 to 18 inches in the southwestern mountains; 4 to 8 inches in northern portions of the park.
* WHERE...Yellowstone National Park.
* WHEN...From late tonight through Wednesday morning. The heaviest snow is expected Tuesday night.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY MORNING

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 12 inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 40 mph.
* WHERE...Jackson Hole.
* WHEN...From late tonight through Wednesday morning. The heaviest snow is expected Tuesday night.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute.

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued March 4 at 3:11AM EST until March 4 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Miami FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...Coastal Palm Beach County.
* WHEN...Through Monday evening.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.

cap:parameter.value: HIGH RIP CURRENT RISK REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 3 at 3:12PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Low pressure tracking into the gulf Tuesday will swing a front towards the panhandle. As the front moves over SE AK, precip is likely for much of the panhandle beginning Tuesday and lasting into Wednesday. The last few days have been clear and cold so the area is set up for snow at the start. At this time, because the expected movement of the front is from west to east, the amounts of snow aren't looking like a real big snow storm.
That being said, beginning late Tuesday evening into Thursday morning, any 12-hour period could produce upwards of 2 to 5 inches of snow around the panhandle. Because of this, 24 hour amounts could reach upwards of 6 to 10 inches. Also, using the NBM 24-hour probability snowfall amounts, there are isolated spots of 10 to 15% chance of seeing 24-hour amounts greater than 12 inches. If confidence increases in those greater amounts, Winter Storm Watches might be needed.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Yakutat; Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan; Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Sitka; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; Annette Island
